subject: RE: [junit] How to test private methods in a class.
msgSnippet: ... Well, obviously you *can*. The question is wether it s *a good idea*. And I don t think there is a definite, all-embracing answer to that question. ... And
messageBody:
> You can't change the
> access modifier of your method just to test it.

Well, obviously you *can*. The question is wether it's *a good idea*. And I
don't think there is a definite, all-embracing answer to that question.

> It is will documented and it works to use java reflection.

And it's more complex than using public methods. Even more importantly,
having to do it is a code smell, in my experience.

> The developers in the project I am currently working changed their
> private methods to public just to UNIT test their code.

What happened as a consequence?

> It is
> currently very important to test the private methods as it accounts
> for over 60% of the functionality and logic. I have found that
> enables me to test bottom up and I have more confidence when coding
> and when I need to refactor.

I have found that methods that are complex enough to warrant explicite
testing want to live in classes where they are naturally public.

Cheers, Ilja
